channel.title: ASF JIRA
channel.description: This file is an XML representation of an issue

item.title: [MAHOUT-1356] Ensure unit tests fail fast when writing outside mvn target directory
item.summary: Ensure unit tests fail fast when writing outside mvn target directory

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.

comments.comment:
Currently all unit tests seem fine when run in parallel mode - no more directory or naming clashes. In order to stop random test failures in the future I would like to see tests fail fast in case they write to some system-global directory - even if that is called /tmp.

One thing to look into in the long run: Configure our surefire to complain when tests mis-behave and store data outside of maven's target directories. Some related documentation and examples so I don't forget it when closing the browser window:

https://svn.apache.org/repos/asf/commons/proper/lang/trunk/src/test/resources/java.policy

http://maven.apache.org/surefire/maven-surefire-plugin/examples/junit.html

First (still failing) try attached soon.

This configuration allows tests to write anywhere - currently there are a few that do write outside of target. Before fixing those I'd like to see all other tests succeed which they currently do not due to some missing permissions I wasn't able to figure out yet.

... succeed when running under restricted permissions I meant to write...

Would be nice if someone with a deeper understanding of that part of Java could take a look - both for verification and for ideas on what exactly is still failing.

Suneel you may want to check out how Apache Lucene/ Solr runs randomized tests in multiple concurrent JVMs – the "allowed" writing space is configured (and enforced) using a security manager. There is some trickery involved because the runner itself must be allowed to write to certain locations, but it's definitely a good source to copy/ paste from.

Isabel Drost-Fromm Dawid Weiss Applied the patch and had to add 3 more permissions to get this going on a Mac.

Added the following permissions (in addition to what's in the patch):

  permission java.lang.RuntimePermission "setDefaultUncaughtExceptionHandler";
  permission java.lang.RuntimePermission "modifyThreadGroup";
  permission java.lang.RuntimePermission "getStackTrace";

Will look at this again tomorrow.

Added a line to the java.policy that allows everything under the target directory.

Fixed a few unit tests by adding getTestTmpDir from MahoutTestCase.

Ted Dunning I updated TDigestTest, it passses, but let me know if it is OK like this. I could not use Mahout.getTestTempDir from the @BeforeClass because it was static so I rearranged the code and put it into @Before and @After.

Tried running the patch today again and now I get

13:28:28 testRetailDataMinSup100(org.apache.mahout.fpm.pfpgrowth.PFPGrowthRetailDataTest)  Time elapsed: 1.47 sec  <<< ERROR!
13:28:28 java.lang.RuntimeException: java.io.IOException: failure to login
13:28:28 	at javax.security.auth.login.LoginContext.invoke(LoginContext.java:862)
13:28:28 	at javax.security.auth.login.LoginContext.access$000(LoginContext.java:205)
13:28:28 	at javax.security.auth.login.LoginContext$5.run(LoginContext.java:697)
13:28:28 	at javax.security.auth.login.LoginContext$5.run(LoginContext.java:695)
13:28:28 	at java.security.AccessController.doPrivileged(Native Method)
13:28:28 	at javax.security.auth.login.LoginContext.invokePriv(LoginContext.java:694)
13:28:28 	at javax.security.auth.login.LoginContext.login(LoginContext.java:602)
13:28:28 	at org.apache.hadoop.security.UserGroupInformation.getLoginUser(UserGroupInformation.java:527)
13:28:28 	at org.apache.hadoop.security.UserGroupInformation.getCurrentUser(UserGroupInformation.java:505)
13:28:28 	at org.apache.hadoop.mapreduce.JobContext.<init>(JobContext.java:80)
13:28:28 	at org.apache.hadoop.mapreduce.Job.<init>(Job.java:100)
13:28:28 	at org.apache.hadoop.mapreduce.Job.<init>(Job.java:104)
13:28:28 	at org.apache.mahout.fpm.pfpgrowth.PFPGrowth.startParallelCounting(PFPGrowth.java:286)
13:28:28 	at org.apache.mahout.fpm.pfpgrowth.PFPGrowth.runPFPGrowth(PFPGrowth.java:209)
13:28:28 	at org.apache.mahout.fpm.pfpgrowth.PFPGrowthRetailDataTest.testRetailDataMinSup100(PFPGrowthRetailDataTest.java:108)

Maybe this has something to do with the support of Hadoop 2?
I don't know which settings to add to the java.policy file. I have tried allowing all AuthPermissions but that did not help either. Any ideas?
You may want to check out how it's configured in Lucene, Frank. Uwe Schindler knows all about those policy files and configured it somehow.

I was pointed to this Lucene policy config by Robert Muir - http://svn.apache.org/repos/asf/lucene/dev/trunk/lucene/tools/junit4/tests.policy

I am having the same issues as Frank's seeing (and hence the reason this didn't make it for 0.9 release). The issues are all related to running MapReduce tests which fail with the exception reported earlier.

Yeah... don't know about MR jobs and what they do (and which policies they might need). You need to dig in the code and see what's causing this exception – very likely it's an avalanche effect and something else is an actual cause...
I debugged the code yesterday and the exception occurs on the LoginContext.login() call inside Hadoop's UserGroupInformation The thing is that I don't know which security rules I have to add.

Seems like the fix would be to add a UserGRoupInformation.doAs or setup a UserAccesToken during the setup() of MapReduce tests to get past this issue. Hadoop's JAAS loginModule kicks in once a Security Manager is enabled. Still looking into this...
Suneel Marthi What exactly do I have to add in the setup method? I like to work on this patch it's just that I don't know this Hadoop authentication API.
I don't know this stuff either but when I chatted with Suneel about it we started to think defining things in a jaas.conf file would be at least part of the solution.

Andrew Musselman Suneel Marthi Can you please provide a bit more context wrt. to what exactly you discussed - preferably including pointers to the Hadoop docs/ JavaDoc your work is based on? If there are no docs, at least a brief summary, maybe involving a sketch in the form of a diff of what direction your patch would take might be helpful to Frank to catch up and help you out here.

I tried to follow along with the things documented in this comment history but still had the "login" errors, even with the same things commented out.

Beyond that I read through stuff like these, but didn't have anything to add beyond "looks like it ought to be in a jaas.conf file":
http://hadoop.apache.org/docs/r1.2.1/Secure_Impersonation.html
http://docs.oracle.com/javase/7/docs/technotes/guides/security/jgss/tutorials/LoginConfigFile.html
Uploading new patch as TDigestTest.java has been removed from codebase as part of the fix for Mahout-1463.

A possible fix after applying the latest uploaded patch. Create a file $MAHOUT_HOME/buildtools/test/resources/jaas.config with the following code in it.

hadoop-simple {
  com.sun.security.auth.module.UnixLoginModule required ;
}

Add the following argument to $MAHOUT_HOME/pom.xml

-Djava.security.auth.login.config=${project.build.directory}/../../buildtools/src/test/resources/jaas.config

Frank, Andrew could u give that a try?
Tried adding the jaas.config but I get the same "failure to login" exception.

Works for me, no "login" errors.

Applied latest patch, added the jaas.conf file, and then referenced it in the pom.

Way to go Suneel Marthi
Ok, nice. Could you commit it? Curious what I left out.
Frank, the patch is not gonna apply cleanly yet; u may have to hand edit it. Did u add the java.security line to pom.xml?
Yes.
Adding to Suneel's last patch, adding jaas.conf and referencing it in pom.xml.
Try this one? I'm on Ubuntu 12.04 for this, what are you running this on?
Please also include java.policy in the patch.
Adding java.policy too.
Patch committed to trunk.

SUCCESS: Integrated in Mahout-Quality #2534 (See https://builds.apache.org/job/Mahout-Quality/2534/)
